info.title: TRM Public API
info.description:
# Welcome to the TRM Labs API

TRM Labs enables risk management and compliance for a global community of financial institutions, cryptocurrency businesses and government agencies. Using the TRM API, you can screen crypto addresses, crypto transactions, and monitor alerts to enable automated solutions and create custom workflows.

TRM provides the following API endpoint categories to its customers:

| Category                                                 | Description                                                                                                                                                                                                      |
| -------------------------------------------------------- | ---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- |
| [**Transaction Monitoring**](#tag/Transfers)             | Transaction Monitoring enables organizations to continuously monitor on-chain transfers to detect suspicious activity that may be indicative of illegal activity such as money laundering or financial crime.    |
| [**Wallet and Entity Screening**](#tag/Screening)        | Wallet and Entity screening enable organizations to receive near real-time intelligence about risk indicators associated with specific cryptocurrency addresses and groups of addresses.                         |
| [**Alert Management**](/#tag/Alerts)                     | Alert Management allows users of the TRM API to obtain information on alerts triggered within a user's environment. Users can also edit the status and information associated with alerts in their organization. |
| [**Rule Management**](/#tag/Rules)                       | Rules Management allows users of the TRM API to obtain details on single or multiple rules within a user's environment.                                                                                          |
| [**Metadata and Informational**](/#tag/Supported-Assets) | TRM maintains informational APIs to allows customers to look up assets available to the Transaction Monitoring API.                                                                                              |

tags.name: Alerts
tags.description: Alerts generated by TRM based on the submitted transfers and the configured rules.

tags.name: Rules
tags.description: User-configured rules which generate alerts based on transfer details.

tags.name: Screening
tags.description: APIs for obtaining quick intelligence about addresses and entities. Users can submit up to five addresses to the Wallet Screening API at one time.

tags.name: Supported Assets
tags.description: API for obtaining a full list of TRM's Supported Assets and Blockchains for Transaction Monitoring.

tags.name: Introduction and Overview
tags.description:
# Welcome to the TRM Labs API

TRM Labs enables risk management and compliance for a global community of financial institutions, cryptocurrency businesses and government agencies. Using the TRM API, you can screen crypto addresses, crypto transactions, and monitor alerts to enable automated solutions and create custom workflows.

TRM provides the following API endpoint categories to its customers:

| Category                                                 | Description                                                                                                                                                                                                      |
| -------------------------------------------------------- | ---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- |
| [**Transaction Monitoring**](#tag/Transfers)             | Transaction Monitoring enables organizations to continuously monitor on-chain transfers to detect suspicious activity that may be indicative of illegal activity such as money laundering or financial crime.    |
| [**Wallet and Entity Screening**](#tag/Screening)        | Wallet and Entity screening enable organizations to receive near real-time intelligence about risk indicators associated with specific cryptocurrency addresses and groups of addresses.                         |
| [**Alert Management**](/#tag/Alerts)                     | Alert Management allows users of the TRM API to obtain information on alerts triggered within a user's environment. Users can also edit the status and information associated with alerts in their organization. |
| [**Rule Management**](/#tag/Rules)                       | Rules Management allows users of the TRM API to obtain details on single or multiple rules within a user's environment.                                                                                          |
| [**Metadata and Informational**](/#tag/Supported-Assets) | TRM maintains informational APIs to allows customers to look up assets available to the Transaction Monitoring API.                                                                                              |

tags.name: Guides
tags.description: A set of guides to help integration the TRM API into your workflow.

tags.name: Authentication
tags.description:
Authentication is done via the API key, which you can find in your [Organization Settings](https://my.trmlabs.com/settings/api-key).

Requests are authenticated using [HTTP Basic Auth](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Basic_access_authentication). Users can authenticate to the API by providing an API key as both the basic auth username and password. This schema is shown in the sample below:

```
response = requests.get(url, params=query, auth=('<YOUR_API_KEY>','<YOUR_API_KEY>'))
```

Users in TRM can create an API key by navigating to **Settings > API Keys > Generate API Key**. Users can also deactivate and rotate API keys on this page.

tags.name: Risk Score Levels
tags.description:
TRM utilizes a 1:1 mapping between numeric risk scores and risk score labels. This is provided only for flexibility purposes. Customers can choose to use the numeric risk score for operations like risk score averaging/arithmetic operations, or operational implementations like integer comparison. Using the equivalency chart below, customers may directly compare numeric risk levels with their labels. | Level | Label | Note | | ------ | ------- | -------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- | | `null` | `null` | Applies only to transfers which have not yet been screened. | | `0` | Unknown | Applies to a wallet or transfer which has been screened,
and no risk has been detected. | | `1` | Low | Low risk | | `5` | Medium | Medium risk | | `10` | High | High risk | | `15` | Severe | Severe risk |

tags.name: Implementation Patterns
tags.description:
## Deposit Workflows

TRM Customers often do not have control over the addresses which serve as sources of funds in case of Deposit transactions (Asset Inflows). This presents a potential risk exposure to services and custodians of individual wallet addresses. TRM Transaction Monitoring helps customers understand both immediate and reescreening risks associated
with these types of transactions. Below is the recommended implementation of TRM's API system to mitigate and prevent risk associated with these transfer types.

1. Once a transfer is received, identify the relevant transaction hash and destination wallet address. Register this transfer with TRM by submitting a `[POST]` call to `https://api.trmlabs.com/public/v2/tm/transfers`
2. TRM will return immediate risk associated with the transfer in question, along with an associated unique identifying code (field name `uuid`) for this transfer. This uuid will always be unique to this specific transfer. In the event that TRM is processing the transfer, the Transaction Monitoring response may include a `screenStatus` value of `"PROCESSING"`. The transfer in this case is still successfully registered with TRM.
3. To receive risk associated with a specific `uuid`, submit a `[GET]` call to `https://api.trmlabs.com/public/v2/tm/transfers/{uuid}`. Once successfully processed, TRM will return a `screenStatus` value of `"SUCCEEDED"`. Relevant alerts will be returned in the response body of this API call, based on the user's Risk Engine configuration.

![Deposit Flow](https://static-assets.trmlabs.com/redoc/generic_api_flow_deposit.png)

## Withdrawal Workflows

TRM Customers often have granular control of withdrawal transactions (Asset Outflows) to an external address. However, the risk associated with this detination address is often not well understood. TRM customers can use a combination of products including Wallet Screening and Transaction Monitoring to better understand, and insulate against, risk associated with these addresses. Below is the recommended implementation of TRM's API system to mitigate and prevent risk associated with these transfer types.

1.  Prior to an initiated transfer, identify the destination wallet address in question
2.  Check the risk indicators on the associated destinated wallet address by submitting a `[POST]` call to `https://api.trmlabs.com/public/v2/screening/addresses`
3.  If the destinated wallet address has risk indicators that fall within your organization's threshold, proceed with the withdrawal transaction.
4.  After the transaction has been confirmed, submit a `[POST]` call to `https://api.trmlabs.com/public/v2/tm/transfers` with the destination address and transaction hash.
5.  TRM will return immediate risk associated with the transfer in question, along with an associated unique identifying code (field name `uuid`) for this transfer. This uuid will always be unique to this specific transfer.

![Withdrawal Flow](https://static-assets.trmlabs.com/redoc/generic_api_flow_withdrawal.png)

tags.name: Frequently Asked Questions
tags.description:
## API Construction ### How do we ensure the chain or asset name we're passing is correct? Is there a way to check with TRM before submitting a reqest? Users can call the Supported Assets API to check the validity of both Blockchain and Asset names. This endpoint is `https://api.trmlabs.com/public/v2/tm/supported-assets`. ### I am receiving the following error: `Cannot read property 'id' of undefined.` What is this? This is a generic error due to a malformed request body on an API request. Likely, a malformed request has been sent into the TRM API endpoint in question. There are typically more descriptive errors that are returned in conjunction with this global, generic error messaging. ## API Functionality ### What is the difference between the `accountExternalId`, `externalId`, `uuid`, and `onchainReference`? Why were things named this way?

These four fields all have differentiated functionality in the TRM application and API. In practice, TRM and its customers need to distinguish between the concepts of a transfer and a transaction.

A transaction in TRM represents a single, unique transaction hash that moves assets from one address to one or more addresses at the same time. A transfer traces a single path of this multi-path transaction. For purposes of differentiating individual components of a larger transaction, the TRM ID naming convention was created.

The externalID is the individual name of a transfer given to TRM by the end user, used to differentiate multiple individual paths in a single transaction. The onchainReference is the transaction hash associated with a specific cryptocurrency transaction. The accountExternalID is a method to identify a specific user identity which may be associated with one or more transactions or wallets (given to TRM by the end user). The uuid is the identifier that TRM uses internally to map the transfer in their own system.

tags.name: API Construction
tags.description:
The TRM API is organized around
[REST](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Representational_state_transfer).

Our API has predictable resource-oriented URLs, accepts
[form-encoded](<https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/POST_(HTTP)#Use_for_submitting_web_forms>)
request bodies, returns [JSON-encoded](http://www.json.org) responses, and
uses standard HTTP response codes, authentication, and verbs.

You can use the TRM API in test mode, which does not affect your live data,
by creating a new organization solely for testing. The API key you use to
authenticate the request determines whether the request is live mode or test
mode.

You can view code examples in the dark area to the right of each API Category, and you can switch
the programming language of the examples with the tabs in the top right. Languages currently available include Python, Javascript, and generic cURL requests.

tags.name: Rate Limiting
tags.description:
Traffic to the TRM API is limited to 10 requests per second per
organization. Requests that come in faster than this limit may receive an
error response with HTTP status code 429. If you are seeing this response,
the solution is to retry these requests after the suggested interval. In
general, your application should meter requests to try to stay at or below
the limit.

### Working with Rate Limits

Rate limiting is a common security mechanism for organizations to prevent large unexpected spikes in the number of API calls from organizations. TRM recommends the following procedures to gracefully handle rate limiting in your implementation.

Organizations can watch for 429 status codes and implement a retry mechanism. Responses to TRM API requests include several headers to help you work with
our rate limit. Responses with a 429 status code will include a `Retry-After` header recommending a number of seconds to wait before retrying the request.

If implementing exponential backoff scheduling to reduce the total amount of requests sent at one time, we encourage you to implement a range of times in which exponential backoff may initiate secondary requests. For example, if you are waiting to send 20 requests in 10 seconds, try sending these requests over a period of a few seconds to avoid generating additional 429 response codes.

tags.name: Error Handling
tags.description:
TRM uses conventional HTTP response codes to indicate the success or failure
of an API request. In general: Codes in the `2xx` range indicate success.
Codes in the `4xx` range indicate an error that failed given the information
provided (e.g., a required parameter was omitted, etc.). Codes in the `5xx`
range indicate an error with TRM's servers (these are rare).

The TRM API uses the following error codes:

| Error Code | Meaning                                                                                                |
| ---------- | ------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------ |
| 400        | Bad Request -- Your request is invalid.                                                                |
| 401        | Unauthorized -- Your API key is wrong.                                                                 |
| 404        | Not Found -- The specified resource could not be found.                                                |
| 405        | Method Not Allowed -- You tried to access an object with an invalid method.                            |
| 406        | Not Acceptable -- You requested a format that isn't json.                                              |
| 429        | Too Many Requests -- You have exceeded your rate limit. See below for details on handling rate limits. |
| 500        | Internal Server Error -- We had a problem with our server. Try again later.                            |
| 503        | Service Unavailable -- We're temporarily offline for maintenance. Please try again later.              |

tags.name: Contact
tags.description:
### Email

If you have any questions or feedback about using the TRM Labs API, please contact us at support@trmlabs.com.

If you are running into an API error, please include any relevant screenshots and API response codes. This ensures our team can help as quickly as possible!

### Live Chat

The Live Chat feature in http://my.trmlabs.com is available for any application or API support questions you may have.

get.description:
Use this API to check on the overall screening state of the transfers you have submitted. Newly submitted transfers will be in the state "PROCESSING" until initial screening is complete, after which point they will have the status "SUCCEEDED" or "FAILED". Failed transfers will have a failure reason available in the `screenStatusFailedReason` field.

On certain chains, TRM provides support only for withdrawals, but may provide support for deposits in the future. Deposits on these chains will be given the status "PENDING".

If TRM's intelligence information changes and the transfer no longer matches the rule, the alert is flagged as "invalid" by setting this field to false. Invalid alerts are still accessible through the user interface and the API and can be managed the same way as other alerts.

account-external-id.description:
The ID that you use to identify the account in your own system. TRM will use this to link transfers by the same account.

NOTE: Only use anonymous identifiers. Do not use email addresses, account names, or other personally identifiable information for this value.

fiat-value.title: FiatValue
fiat-value.description: The value of the transfer measured in USD. The base unit for this field is dollars, not cents. For a $100 transfer, submit `"100"` or `"100.00"`. Values must be 0 or positive.

timestamp.description: Onchain transaction timestamp of the transfer to be screened, formatted as an ISO-8601 UTC datetime.

transfer-type.description:
This indicates the _direction_ of the transfer.

- `CRYPTO_WITHDRAWAL`: Transfer was made FROM a familiar address TO a `destinationAddress` of unknown risk.
- `CRYPTO_DEPOSIT`: The transfer was made TO a familiar `destinationAddress` FROM one or more senders of unknown risk.

asset.description: The symbol of a supported crypto asset. See "Supported Assets and Blockchains" for valid values.

assetAmount.description: The value of the transfer measured in units of the crypto asset.

chain.description: The name of a supported blockchain. See "Supported Assets and Blockchains" for valid values. The transfer will be stored with TRM's internal representation of the chain's name, so we recommend not matching against chain name on data returned from the API.

destinationAddress.description: The recipient of the transfer. For deposits, this will be the deposit address controlled by the VASP. For withdrawals, this will be a possibly unidentified counterparty. The transfer will be stored with TRM's normalized version of the address, so we recommend not matching against destinationAddress on data returned from the API.

externalId.description: The ID that you use to identify the transfer in your own system. This field must be unique per transfer. Additional transfers using the same `externalId` will be ignored.

onchainReference.description: Onchain transaction hash for the transfer to be screened.

displayName.description: Provided for named entities and null for addresses and wallet clusters.

alerts.description: Always null in response to a POST request.

asset.description: The name of a supported asset. See "Supported Assets and Blockchains" for valid values.

chain.description: The name of a supported blockchain. See "Supported Assets and Blockchains" for valid values. The transfer will be stored with TRM's internal representation of the chain's name, so we recommend not matching against chain name on data returned from the API.

destinationAddress.description: The recipient addres of the transfer, converted to TRM's normalized format.

onchainReference.description: Onchain transaction hash for the transfer to be screened.

screenStatusFailedReason.description:
- `INVALID_ONCHAIN_REFERENCE`: If the transaction hash could not be found on the given blockchain, TRM will reattempt the search for several hours to give the network time to propagate a potentially new transaction. If the transaction still cannot be found, the transfer screen will be failed with this status.
- `INVALID_DESTINATION_ADDRESS`: The transaction was found on the blockchain, but the `destinationAddress` provided was not a recipient in the transaction.
- `null`: The transfer is still in screening or has successfully been screened. Any alerts for this screened transfer can be found on the `/public/v2/tm/transfer-alerts` endpoint.
